column207: The data vis work is considered a minor aspect of the overall product we produce and I volunteered to take ownership due to my experience and skills in dataviz. This unfortunately made me more aware of the lack of interest, lack of data respect and knowledge from leadership and executives. The product would benefit from more focus on the data viz as it can provide feedback into the other aspects of the product (which we are building separate tools for), help clients understand the product better (wehich we are also building separate tools for), etc., but as always, resources are 'better placed elsewhere'.

column207: It's hard to perform software engineering and also academic writing. Successful software is not appreciated in peer review, and successful academic projects are not useful to the general public due to complexity. Trying to shoe-horn a project to fit both audiences causes it to fail in both arenas, and also means that I am learning software engineering simultaneously alongside advanced computer science and machine learning research topics

column205: Other: I'm still working on convincing my team about the value of user-centred design, UX/UI as it applies to data viz. They aren't opposed to it, just unfamiliar, so it's hard to continuously advocate/remind for its integration.
column206: Other: A prototyping tool solely dedicated to data visualizations. These are often baked into Adobe XD and Sketch through sub-optimal plug-ins. I have to create visualizations by hand - super finicky and ineffective. It would also be great if there was more of a general awareness of the value of UXD in data viz, and a priority to explore it.
column207: It's not that they don't get it - I just have to continue to demonstrate the value of UXD. I've only been in the role three months, but I believe there is opportunity to educate and engage staff + leadership in this. In my organization, I feel the openness is there.

column205: Other: Bad terminology in data visualization community dilutes its ability to be effective. When everything is data vis (including non-visualization techniques) then nothing is data visualization. Over the past decade people have asked for my visualization skills for meditation, powerpoint design, memorization techniques, sketch noting, graphic design, drawing, etc. Other big frustrations include lack of ethics in data vis and that a lot of it is pseudo-science. People learned something from Tufte and now that’s just considered the way to do things. It’s madness.
column220: Lack of ethical standards for visualizing data
column226: I don't feel I need to improve my data visualization skills currently
column235: Other: Seeing critiques of existing visualizations by practitioners and experts. Oh and academic papers from IEEE VIS.
column236: Ethics: Alberto Cairo. But either journalism (ProPublica e.g. Lena Groeger or 538) or health tech (fitbit/Apple/23andme). I like Malofiej.

column207: Quality and Speed do not move in the same direction. Agile is an awful methodology for Data Viz work. Requirements gathering is the ones most important step in any good data viz, Data viz will not read their minds or answer every question they can come up with, it isn't just pretty or a nice to have, it's meant to help them consume large amounts of complex data more efficiently. Charts are meant to be read, not to be stared at.
